ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about democracy around the world and had some engaging conversations about foreign policy
We discussed a lot about democracy and how to strengthen our democratic institutions.

It was very helpful to learn from a practitioner. Dr. Young is a very cool person and political consultant (and TV show developer?!), and she cares deeply about her students. I gained some insight from hearing what news she pays attention to, and what articles/sources she reads. 

I also learned the skill of being concise. Dr. Young would give us essay prompts that had very broad (but also excellent) questions, and we would have 5-7 pages to respond. And she expected nuance and policy proposals! I am so grateful for this; I am used to the Yale tradition of writing 30 pages on specific questions; what Dr. Young had us do is much more similar to what those creating briefs/memos would have to do.
I honed my ability to research broad topics and discuss my ideas in a highly educated environment.
I learned some things about contemporary problems in democracies
I learned about the theory of democracy, especially with respect to foreign affairs. In class, we debated contemporary political questions and applied democratic theory to them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: strong conversations in class, good group of people
Weaknesses: very long readings that are not really helpful or necessary for class discussion. The conversations are interesting, but not always cogent
It is very well designed for student discussion with very engaging readings. Perhaps there could be less focus on the US.

I do think we spent a little too much time discussing current events, which made the class discussion at the end feel rushed. There is so much to talk about in a course about geopolitics! Other than that, I can only speak positively about this class. Dr. Young's feedback on our essays was remarkable; I have never felt so closely-read by a professor.

Professor Young is a great professor and is incredibly knowledgeable about the subjects we discuss. Sometimes I hope she would push back harder against other students and myself when we provide controversial opinions or factually dubious claims.
It is a very engaging class. I think it could be improved by slightly more guidance of discussions from Dr. Young.
I would assign fewer readings and structure class discussions around them a little more

The strengths are really interesting, if overly long, readings for every class and interesting essay questions. The main weakness was the unfocused debates in class that revolved mainly around contemporary domestic politics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Probably, because it's worth having conversations in class and with Dr. Young. The readings are somewhat long and never really tied to class discussion. The essays are interesting, the courseload is not too bad. Altogether, pretty good class but not life changing.
I would, especially to those who are still learning their specialty in the field of PLSC/GLBL etc.
I absolutely would! The course is awesome, but the real star is Dr. Young.
I would, if you want to discuss politics and democratic theory with other Yalies.
